channel.title: Memcached on Tech Notebook
channel.description: Recent content in Memcached on Tech Notebook

item.title: Memcached: Setting up a Cache Server for Apache
item.description:
Introduction link

Memcached is a caching server that helps accelerate client requests.

Setup link

Here’s documentation for setting up a memcached cache server:

Installing memcached And The PHP5 memcache Module

Other link

To get statistics on memcached and calculate hits and ratios:

 echo -en "stats\r\n" "quit\r\n" | nc localhost 11211 | tr -s [:cntrl:] " "| cut -f42,48 -d" " | sed "s/\([0-9]*\)\s\([0-9]*\)/ \2\/\1*100/" | bc -l

item.title: Setting up Memcached on WordPress
item.description:
Introduction link

Memcached is a cache server that, unlike some PHP accelerators, does not consume additional CPU. It’s therefore an ideal compromise. For WordPress, there is currently no simple solution to quickly set up this solution (although it’s not very time-consuming anyway).

Installation link

On Debian, it’s easy:

 apt-get install memcached

Your memcached server is now running on port 11211.

Configuration link

Server link

Nothing special needs to be done, the basic configuration is sufficient.
